DOC.HEAD: Rebuilding Carrier To Shift Focus To Atlanta
Eds: LEADS with 6 new grafs to reflect American announcement of purchase of Eastern's Latin American routes. Picks up 7th graf pvs ``Eastern officials ...''
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines' sale of its Latin American routes highlights a declining role for its traditional Miami base, while the rebuilding carrier puts its emphasis on Atlanta. Pan American World Airways and American Airlines, the buyer of the Latin routes, expect their Miami expansion plans to be bolstered by Eastern's cutbacks in Miami, where it is the No. 1 carrier. In its presentation to creditors in New York on Monday, Eastern disclosed the planned ``de-hubbing'' of Miami because it ``has been a source of heavy losses.'' Creditors were told Eastern's planned sale of Latin American routes, to American, would enable Eastern to ``re-focus on Atlanta as the airline's major hub.'' The sale of the routes and certain other assets to American for $471 million was confirmed late Tuesday in an announcement from American. Eastern's revised business plan is ``quite similar'' to its original rebuilding plan devised last April, as the carrier tried to recover from a crippling strike. Eastern in August decided to keep its Latin routes, but recently resumed negotiations with American because of concerns about a cash shortfall. Company spokesman Robin Matell declined to elaborate on the future of the Miami and Atlanta operations. Eastern officials in the past said there were no plans to move Eastern's corporate headquarters from Miami to Atlanta, but wouldn't speculate on whether that was a possibility later. Eastern has 260 departures from Atlanta, where it is second to Delta Airlines. It had 285 departures from Atlanta before the strike. Eastern spokespeople said no projections were available Tuesday on the total flights planned for Atlanta. Before the March 4 strike, Eastern operated about 10 percent of its daily schedule of 1,040 flights out of Miami. Eastern officials had said recently that sale of the Latin routes could leave as few as 24 Miami departures daily. Eastern, building back while in Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization, is back to 76 daily departures from Miami. Peter Reavely, chief of aviation development at Miami International Airport, said he expects New York-based Pan Am to become the airport's major carrier between Miami and the Northeast, and Texas-based American would dominate between Miami and Sun Belt destinations. ``The effect is positive for us,'' Pan Am spokeswoman Pamela Hanlon said of Eastern's plans. ``One of the primary reasons (for) building up Miami was to fill the void left by Eastern's diminished operations. What they are saying regarding the `de-hubbing' supports the decision we made earlier.'' Pan Am has boosted its daily Miami departures to 70, from 48 one year ago. American has 36 departures from Miami, is expanding its American Eagle commuter service there, and has made Miami the headquarters for its new Florida-Caribbean-Latin Services Division. ``We see Miami as a very important part of the American system, particularly feeding traffic from the Caribbean,'' American spokesman Ed Stewart said.
